sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Lennox-Gastaut syndrome - Seizure; Adjunct: Initial, 400 to 800 mg/day ORALLY in 2 equally divided doses with food; increase by 400 to 800 mg/day every other day to a MAX dose of 3200 mg/day in 2 equally divided doses

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• Lennox-Gastaut syndrome - Seizure; Adjunct: (1 year to younger than 17 years) 10 mg/kg/day ORALLY in 2 equally divided doses with food; increase by 10 mg/kg every other day to a target dose of 45 mg/kg/day or 3200 mg/day (whichever is less) in 2 equally divided doses
  • Lennox-Gastaut syndrome - Seizure; Adjunct: (17 years or older) Initial, 400 to 800 mg/day ORALLY in 2 equally divided doses with food; increase by 400 to 800 mg/day every other day to a MAX dose of 3200 mg/day in 2 equally divided doses

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• Renal impairment, CrCl less than 30 mL/min: No dosage adjustment necessary
  • Hepatic impairment, severe (Child-Pugh 10 to 15): Use not recommended
  • Hepatic impairment, mild to moderate (Child-Pugh 5 to 9): Use caution
  • Hemodialysis: Consider dosage adjustment as exposure may be reduced by about 30%
  • Concomitant valproate therapy: Initiate rufinamide at a dosage less than 400 mg/day in adults, and less than 10 mg/kg/day children

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: Familial Short QT syndrome; may increase risk of sudden death and ventricular arrhythmias by shortening the QT interval

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- QT interval shortening has been reported; increased risk with concomitant use of drugs with QT-shortening potential
  • Dermatologic:
  • -- Rash may indicate multiorgan hypersensitivity syndrome; monitoring recommended
  • Hematologic:
  • -- Leukopenia has been reported
  • Hepatic:
  • -- Mild to moderate hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh 5 to 9); use with caution
  • -- Severe hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh score 10 to 15); use not recommended
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Multiorgan hypersensitivity syndrome has been reported and typically presents with fever and rash in addition to other organ involvement; discontinue if reaction is suspected
  • Neurologic:
  • -- Somnolence, fatigue, coordination abnormalities, dizziness, gait disturbances, and ataxia have been reported; driving or operating machinery not recommended until effects are realized
  • -- Status epilepticus has been reported
  • Other:
  • -- Abrupt discontinuation should be avoided to minimize risk of status epilepticus, seizure precipitation or exacerbation
  • Psychiatric:
  • -- Suicidal behavior or ideation may occur; monitor patients for new onset or worsening depression, suicidal thoughts or behavior, or unusual changes in mood or behavior
  • Renal:
  • -- Hemodialysis; consider dose adjustment
  • Concomitant Use:
  • -- Efficacy of hormonal contraceptives may be reduced with rufinamide therapy; additional nonhormonal forms of contraception are recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Shortened QT interval (46% to 65%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (7% to 12%), Vomiting (Adults, 5%; pediatric, 17% to 24%)
  • Neurologic:Ataxia (4% to 5.4%), Dizziness (2.7% to 19%), Headache (16% to 27%), Somnolence (11% to 24%)
  • Ophthalmic:Blurred vision (6%), Diplopia (4% to 9%)
  • Other:Fatigue (9% to 16%)
Serious
  • Hematologic:Leukopenia (3.7%)
  • Immunologic:Drug hypersensitivity syndrome
  • Neurologic:Status epilepticus (0.9% to 4.1%)
  • Psychiatric:Suicidal behavior

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: The exact mechanism of action is unknown. In vitro studies suggests that rufinamide, a triazole derivative, modulates the activity of sodium channels and subsequently prolongs the inactive state of the channel.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Bioavailability, Oral: 85%
  • Effect of food: 34% increase
  • Tmax, Oral: 4 to 6 hours

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono: Liver, extensive and primarily by carboxylesterase(s) mediated hydrolysis

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • Give with food.
  • Tablets may be administered whole, as half tablets, or crushed.
  • (Suspension) Shake well before using.
  • (Suspension) Use the provided adapter and calibrated oral dosing syringe to measure and administer the medication.
  • (Suspension) Discard any remaining supply 90 days after opening.

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• seizure control indicates efficacy
  • emergence or worsening of depression, suicidal thoughts or behavior, or any unusual changes in mood or behavior
  • rash; may indicate multi-organ hypersensitivity reactions (fever, elevated liver function tests, hematuria, and lymphadenopathy)
  • seizure precipitation or exacerbation, or status epilepticus upon abrupt discontinuation

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
RUFINAMIDE
USES: A triazole derivative used to treat seizures associated with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome in adults and in children 4 years of age and older. PHARMACOLOGY: The exact mechanism of action is unknown. In vitro studies suggest that rufinamide modulates the activity of sodium channels and subsequently prolongs the inactive state of the channel. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Overdose is very rare. MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Overdose information is limited. An adult received an overdose of 7200 mg/day of rufinamide during clinical trials and did not experience any major adverse effects. SEVERE TOXICITY: Based on limited data, none reported. ADVERSE EFFECTS: COMMON: Somnolence, nausea, vomiting, headache, fatigue and dizziness. Other adverse effects that may occur: decreased appetite, rash, pruritus, ataxia, diplopia, blurred vision, abdominal pain, multiorgan hypersensitivity syndrome, shortening of the QT interval, and suicidal thinking or behavior.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
RUFINAMIDE
  • Support: MANAGEMENT OF MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. MANAGEMENT OF SEVERE TOXICITY: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive; treat seizures with benzodiazepines.
  • Decontamination: PREHOSPITAL: Gastrointestinal decontamination is not recommended because of the potential for CNS depression and seizures. HOSPITAL: Consider activated charcoal for a recent large ingestion and if the patient is able to maintain airway or airway is protected.
  • Airway management: Assess airway; intubation and ventilation may be necessary in patients with significant CNS depression.
  • Antidote: None.
  • Seizure: Administer IV benzodiazepines; barbiturates or propofol may be needed, if seizures persist or recur.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor ECG (for QTc shortening), mental status, fluid and electrolytes in symptomatic patients.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: A limited amount of drug may be dialyzable in overdose. There was a 29% reduction in rufinamide AUC in patients undergoing dialysis 3 hours after a rufinamide dose. Hemodialysis is unlikely to be necessary, and it should only be considered in patients with life-threatening toxicity.
  • Patient disposition: OBSERVATION CRITERIA: All patients with deliberate self-harm ingestions should be evaluated in a healthcare facility and monitored until symptoms resolve. Children with unintentional ingestions who are symptomatic should be observed in a healthcare facility. ADMISSION CRITERIA: A patient with a deliberate ingestion that demonstrates seizure activity, or other persistent neurotoxicity should be admitted. CONSULT CRITERIA: Call a Poison Center for assistance in managing patients with severe toxicity or in whom the diagnosis is unclear.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
RUFINAMIDE
TOXICITY: A specific toxic dose has not been established. An adult received an overdose of 7200 mg/day of rufinamide and did not experience any major adverse effects. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: ADULTS: Initial dose is 400 to 800 mg/day orally given in 2 equally divided doses; increase by 400 to 800 mg/day every 2 days to a maximum dose of 3200 mg/day. PEDIATRIC: Children 4 years of age or older: Initial dose is 10 mg/kg/day orally given in 2 equally divided doses; increase by 10 mg/kg every other day until 45 mg/kg/day or 3200 mg/day is reached (whichever is less).

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to avoid activities requiring mental alertness or coordination until drug effects are realized, as drug may cause dizziness, drowsiness, and motor incoordination.
  • Counsel patient drug may decrease effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (pills, implants, or IUDs). Alternative or additional forms of birth control are recommended.
  • Drug may cause headache, fatigue, and nausea.
  • Instruct patient to report worsening depression, suicidal ideation, or unusual changes in behavior.
  • Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of serious dermatologic reactions, as this may be associated with multi-organ hypersensitivity syndrome.
  • Instruct patient to take tablets and suspension with food.
  • Instruct patients on proper use of dosing adapter and calibrated dosing syringe for use with oral suspension.
  • Use the suspension within 90 days of first opening the bottle, then discard any remainder
  • Advise patient against sudden discontinuation as this may precipitate status epilepticus.
  • Counsel patient to avoid alcohol.
